title: I.N.S. Thwarts Basic Justice
body:
To the Editor:

Anthony Lewis's Sept. 21 and Oct. 5 columns on the Immigration and Naturalization Service's treatment of Hawa 
Said, a Yemeni immigrant who claims she should be tried as a citizen, only mentions in passing that Ms. Said was 
convicted of drug trafficking. If she had led a life free of crime, would she have become involved with the I.N.S. at 
all?

Mr. Lewis's question, "Why bring a dubious, marginal case like that against Ms. Said?", prompts this reply: A 
deportation case stemming from a conviction for a criminal act should be moved to the front of the huge backlog of 
work the I.N.S. is trying to overcome. The processing of Ms. Said's deportation case arises from her being jailed for 
the greater evil of drug trafficking; this is a critical, not a marginal, factor.

 

STEVE DELL'OLIO

Stamford, Conn., Oct. 6, 1999

http://www.nytimes.com
